summary: This document is a chain of email correspondence from 2019 between U.S. Department of Justice staff, primarily concerning travel approval requests for federal prosecutors and investigators to conduct interviews in West Palm Beach, Florida, and Los Angeles, California, as part of the ongoing investigation into Jeffrey Epstein (case 2018R01618). The emails detail logistical planning, approval processes, and references to prior travel for victim interviews.

persons.name: Tyrrell
persons.context: Mentioned as the official whose approval is required for travel authorization requests submitted through the E2 system.

connections.description: S must submit travel requests through a system that requires approval from Tyrrell, indicating Tyrrell is in an approving authority role for S's travel.

events.title: Planned Interview in West Palm Beach
events.description: Federal investigators planned to travel to West Palm Beach, Florida, to conduct an interview related to the Epstein investigation, requesting a hotel conference room for the purpose.

events.title: Victim Interview in Los Angeles
events.description: A prior travel request was made for investigators to fly to Los Angeles to conduct a victim interview, also requesting a hotel conference room.

events.title: Meetings and Interviews in West Palm Beach
events.description: Travel was requested for approximately three days for meetings and interviews with victims in West Palm Beach, Florida, as part of the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Travel for Meetings and Interviews
events.description: Travel was requested for meetings and interviews in West Palm Beach, Florida, for the case United States v. Epstein.

events.title: Travel for Meetings in Florida
events.description: Initial travel request for two days of meetings and interviews in West Palm Beach and/or Fort Lauderdale, Florida, for the Epstein investigation.

keyFacts: The document references the federal criminal case 'United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618', described as 'an investigation relating to enticement of minors for sexual activity'.
Multiple travel requests in 2019 show ongoing investigative activity, including victim interviews, in West Palm Beach, Florida, and Los Angeles, California.
Investigators routinely requested permission to reserve hotel conference rooms to conduct interviews, indicating formal interview settings were used.
The correspondence reveals internal DOJ travel approval procedures and the use of a system called 'E2 Solutions' for authorizations.
The emails are between DOJ staff, with the primary requester being an Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York.
